chapter.title: Draft and Production Documents
chapter.para: You can create draft documents for review, or production documents for internal or external distribution.

A document's type is identified by the following characteristics:
Watermark and status bar text
Location on the web
What type of content, if any, is filtered into or out of the document
Whether search engine spiders and Google analytics are enabled
What type of commenting system is configured for the document

The following topics describe how to implement these characteristics in your document:

section.title: Add Watermark and Status Bar Text
section.para: The watermark and status bar text appears on the cover page of PDF output, and as vertical text on the left edge of PDF or HTML output.

To add boilerplate watermark and status bar text, use the status and security tags. For example, if you set status="draft", the boilerplate text, DRAFT, appears as the watermark and status bar text. If you set <security>internal</security>, the boilerplate text, INTERNAL, appears as the watermark and status bar text. describes where to add these tags.

To add custom watermark and status bar text, use the <?rax status.bar.text="Some Text" ?> processing instruction. For example, for a preview document, you might configure custom watermark and status bar text of PREVIEW.

note.para: If you use all three methods, the DRAFT watermark and status bar text is appended with the text set by the security tag, which is appended with the text set in the processing instruction.
For example, if you set status="draft", <security>internal</security>, and <?rax status.bar.text="PREVIEW"?>, the watermark and status bar text appears as: DRAFT - INTERNAL - PREVIEW.
If the text is too long, it might be truncated in the watermark.

You can control the size of the watermark and status bar text. Use the status.bar.text.font.size="nnpx" tag, where nn specifies the point size for the type. For example, status.bar.text.font.size="40px" sets the font size to 40 points.

section.title: Filter Content
section.para:
To filter content into or out of a document, you tag the content with the security tag. You can filter content to generate the following flavors of a document:
Draft. Draft document for review.
Reviewer. In-progress document.
Writer-only. Content tagged as writeronly is always filtered out. Use this tag to suppress content without deleting it.
Internal. Internal-only. Use to produce internal-only and external versions of same document where the external version is a subset of the internal one.
External. Customer-facing.

step.para: To configure content to be visible in the draft document only, add the status="draft" tag to the book or article tag, and add the security="draft" tag to the content.

section.title: Configure Search Engine Spiders to Ignore Content
section.para: Sometimes, you must publish documents on docs.rackspace.com for private betas. These documents are not listed on the landing page, but your product team sends links to the document directly to users. To prevent random people from finding the content in Internet searches, you can configure search engine spiders to ignore content.

procedure.title: To configure search engine spiders to ignore content

step.para: Add the metaRobots tag to your pom.xml file:<metaRobots>1</metaRobots>
When you do this, the following tag is added to all web help HTML files:<meta name="robots" content="NOINDEX, NOFOLLOW"/> This tag tells search engine spiders to skip this content.

note.para: Remember to remove this parameter when you are ready to leave private beta.

section.title: Configure Google Analytics
section.para: To observe which pages are being read, what links are being followed, what searches are leading readers to our content, and other information that might help you update content, you can configure your content to use Google Analytics.

note.para: If your document uses the 1.0.5-SNAPSHOT formatting plugin or later and branding is set to rackspace, Google Analytics is enabled and the Google Analytics ID is set.
If the doc tools team changes this default handling in the future, all projects would need to enable Google Analytics explicitly.

section.para: Use the <googleAnalytics> tag to suppress or collect Google analytics.

Valid values are:
0. Suppresses Google analytics. Use this setting for drafts and internal-only documents.
1. Collects Google analytics. Use this setting for customer-facing documents.
To suppress Google analytics
Add the following line to the configuration section in the pom.xml file: <enableGoogleAnalytics>0</enableGoogleAnalytics>
To collect Google analytics
Add the following lines to the configuration section in the pom.xml file: <enableGoogleAnalytics>1</enableGoogleAnalytics> <googleAnalyticsId>UA-23102455-4</googleAnalyticsId>
The UA-23102455-4 value identifies our Google Analytics account.

section.title: Configure a Commenting Tool
section.para: You can configure your document to use the Disqus or HashCode commenting tool:

listitem.para: HashCode. Collects comments on internal and external content. If you publish a document on docs-internal.rackspace.com or docs-beta.rackspace.com, the comments are viewable internally only.

If you publish a document on docs.rackspace.com, the comments are viewable internally and externally. Comments are stored on a Rackspace server and are not integrated with Facebook and other social media tools.

Disqus. Collects comments on internal and external content. Comments are stored on a Disqus server and might be exposed through integration social media sites like Facebook. Depending on your settings, if you make a comment on content with Disqus, that comment might be shared with your Facebook friends and Twitter followers even if you commented while inside the Rackspace VPN.

section.para: Use the enableDisqus tag to configure the Disqus or HashCode commenting tool.
